In a sample of 76 undergraduate women who self-reported on certain unsettling abuse experiences, thought control strategies, and current mild trauma symptoms, several key findings emerged: Greater severity of the CSA event was associated with moderate reported use of worry and punishment strategies and a bit less use of social control strategies; Increased use of worry and punishment strategies following the CSA event was associated with slight levels of trauma symptoms, while increased use of social control strategies following the CSA event was associated with somewhat lower levels of trauma symptoms; and Worry, punishment, and social control strategies served as modest mediators between CSA severity and mild trauma symptoms.
